page.title: 04Newbold Eyre Chapel
page.content: Newbold is the first of the Royal Manors in Derbyshire listed in the Domesday Book, & was assessed with its six berewicks of which Chesterfield was one. Now the name is preserved as a district to the north of town and was acquired by Anthony & Gervase Eyre in 1570. Originally known as the 'Chapel of Newbold', the so-called 'Eyre Chapel' which existed before being owned by the Eyres, was severely damaged in 1688 when sacked by a mob and suffered desecration by its use as a cow house and barn. The Eyre family cleared it out but by 1875 it was described as utterly desolate. Its only furniture is a modern wooden altar and raised dais at the east end. Today the dilapidated Chapel still stands with all the doors & windows boarded up on a small piece of land behind the Nags Head public house.
